quoteFirst: The animal could be easily turned on its back. It weighed at this time 28.57 kilos. On June 9, at
quoteLast: , the temperature was 103.4°F. The sheep still did not eat, but had no diarrhea. It now weighed 27.9 kilos, and the temperature was 103°F. at 10.45 a.m.
title: Barium: A Cause of the Loco-Weed Disease
author: Crawford, Albert C. (Albert Cornelius), 1869-1921

quoteFirst: On January 6th, at 7 A.M., the pre-Dreadnought battleship _King Edward VII._, of the 3rd Battle Squadron, left Scapa for Belfast to refit, and at
quoteLast: , when in Lat. 58.43 N., Long. 4.12 W., a violent explosion occurred under the starboard engine-room. Captain Maclachlan first reported that the ship had been torpedoed, but later came to the conclusion that she had been mined, as was eventually found to be, undoubtedly, the case.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: She was the _Pernambuco_ of the Hamburg South American Line--from Lulea to Stettin with iron ore (3500 tons). Sent crew off in boats and sank her. Her chief officer stated her to be of 7000 tons. 6.55 A.M.: Chased, boarded, and sank the _Johannes Russ_ of Hamburg--same routine as previously.
quoteLast: : Hove to the German ship _Dal Alfven_, and ordered her to abandon ship. A destroyer was with her, and approached me at speed.
title: The Story of Our Submarines
author: Bower, John Graham, 1886-1940

quoteFirst: On November 19, 1918, the Battalion started on the long march to the Rhine. We crossed the German border near St. Vith at 10.08 a.m., December 5th, with the Union Jack flying at the head of the column. At
quoteLast: , December 13th, the Battalion crossed the Rhine at Bonn and proceeded to the “Cologne Bridgehead Outpost Line,” where we had the satisfaction of telling the Hun how he should act and also the pleasure of enforcing our instructions on him.
title: Nova Scotia's Part in the Great War
author: Hunt, M. S.‏ (Markland Stuart)‏ [Editor]

quoteLast: to 1:33 p. m.; Santa Fé, New Mex., 8:59 to 11:49 a. m.; Wheeling, W. Va., 11:32 a. m. to 2:13 p. m.; Washington, D. C., 11:58 a. m. to 2:31 p. m.; Louisville, Ky., 11:03 a. m. to 1:44 p.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, March 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
